A [[folk etymology]] claims that it derives from a compound of the [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]] words ''alo'' meaning "presence", "front", "face", or "share"; and ''ha'', meaning "breath of life" or "essence of life." Although ''alo'' does indeed mean "presence" etc., the word for breath is spelled with a macron or kÄhako over the a (hÄ) whereas the word aloha does not have a long a.

==Usage==
  +
Before contact with the West, the words used for greeting were ''welina'' and ''anoai.'' Today, "aloha kakahiaka" is the phrase for "good morning." "Aloha {{okina}}auinalÄ" means "good afternoon" and "aloha ahiahi" means "good evening." "Aloha kÄkou" is a common form of "welcome to all."
  +   +
In modern Hawai{{okina}}i, numerous businesses have aloha in their names, with more than 3 pages of listings in the O{{okina}}ahu phone book alone.
